questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding cavernous sinus thrombosis EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Loss of jaw jerk.
• The jaw jerk reflex is mediated via the trigeminal nerve (V3 motor root), but this is not affected in cavernous sinus thrombosis.
• Cavernous sinus thrombosis typically involves cranial nerves III, IV, V1, V2, and VI, but not the motor root of V3, hence jaw jerk remains intact.

questions.text: Marked joint is which of the following type ?

Pivot

The red arrow in the image points to the proximal radioulnar joint.
• This joint is formed between the head of the radius and the radial notch of the ulna, held together by the annular ligament.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the “A” marked muscle
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Superior Gluteal nerve

the muscle labeled 'A' is the gluteus medius, and its primary nerve supply is the superior gluteal nerve. This nerve is crucial for the function of the gluteus medius, which is a major abductor and medial rotator of the thigh at the hip joint. The superior gluteal nerve arises from the sacral plexus, specifically from the L4, L5, and S1 nerve roots, and it innervates not only the gluteus medius but also the gluteus minimus and the tensor fasciae latae muscles. Proper functioning of these muscles is essential for stabilizing the pelvis when walking, running, and standing on one leg.

questions.text: Which of the following is false
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A is Abductor pollicis brevis

• A is Abductor pollicis brevis (False): The muscle labeled 'A' is located on the dorsal (back) side of the forearm and is part of the anatomical snuff box. This muscle is the Extensor Pollicis Brevis, which extends the thumb. The Abductor Pollicis Brevis is a muscle on the palmar (front) side of the hand, part of the thenar eminence.
• B is Extensor pollicis brevis (Correct): The muscle labeled 'B' is indeed the Extensor pollicis brevis. It helps to extend and abduct the thumb.
• C is Extensor pollicis longus (Correct): The muscle labeled 'C' is the Extensor pollicis longus. It is the primary extensor of the thumb.
• D is Extensor indicis (Correct): The muscle labeled 'D' is the Extensor indicis. It is a slender muscle that lies medial to the extensor pollicis longus and extends the index finger independently.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman received a first-degree burn on her neck, arm, and forearm from a house fire. Which of the following skin structures or functions is most likely damaged or impaired?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Exocrine gland secretion

Explanation:
• A first-degree burn involves only the epidermis.
• Damage includes erythema, pain, and swelling but no blistering (since dermis is intact).
• Structures in the epidermis such as sweat gland ducts, sebaceous gland ducts, and openings of exocrine glands are impaired → hence exocrine gland secretion is affected.

choices.text: C is the afferent part of Basal nuclei
D has combination of sensory and motor fibres

questions.text: Which of the following is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

C is the afferent part of Basal nuclei

• A is insular cortex (True): The structure labeled A is the insular cortex, also known as the insula. It's a deep-seated cortical region located within the lateral sulcus, which separates the temporal and frontal lobes. The insula plays a crucial role in a wide range of functions, including sensory processing, emotion, and interoception (awareness of the body's internal state).
• B is biggest relay centre (True): The structure labeled B is the thalamus. It is indeed the largest and most significant relay station in the brain. Nearly all sensory and motor information (with the exception of olfaction) passes through the thalamus before being routed to the cerebral cortex for processing.
• C is the afferent part of Basal nuclei (False): The structure labeled C is the caudate nucleus, which is part of the striatum. The striatum (composed of the caudate nucleus and the putamen) is the primary afferent (input) nucleus of the basal ganglia. Therefore, the statement is false because the caudate nucleus itself is only a component of the afferent part, not the entirety of the "afferent part of the basal nuclei." The putamen is another major component of the afferent part.
• D has combination of sensory and motor fibres (True): The structure labeled D is the internal capsule. It is a major white matter pathway composed of a dense collection of ascending and descending nerve fibers. It contains both sensory fibers (e.g., those from the thalamus to the cortex) and motor fibers (e.g., the corticospinal tract, which carries commands for voluntary movement from the cortex to the spinal cord). Due to its crucial location and the concentration of vital pathways, strokes or lesions in the internal capsule can lead to severe motor and sensory deficits.

choices.text: A is Post Sup Alveolar Nerve
C – injury here causes loss of lacrimation
D – injury here causes loss of lacrimation

questions.text: Which of the following is false ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

D – injury here causes loss of lacrimation

• A is Post Sup Alveolar Nerve (True): Structure 'A' is the posterior superior alveolar nerve. This nerve branches off the maxillary nerve (V2) in the pterygopalatine fossa. It descends on the posterior surface of the maxilla to supply the maxillary molars, premolars, and the lining of the maxillary sinus.
• B receives Vidian Nerve (True): Structure 'B' is the pterygopalatine ganglion, a major parasympathetic ganglion located in the pterygopalatine fossa. It is a key relay center that receives the Vidian nerve (also known as the nerve of the pterygoid canal). The Vidian nerve is formed by the union of the greater petrosal nerve (carrying preganglionic parasympathetic fibers from the facial nerve) and the deep petrosal nerve (carrying postganglionic sympathetic fibers from the internal carotid plexus). These fibers synapse in the ganglion.
• C – injury here causes loss of lacrimation (True): Structure 'C' is the zygomatic nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve (V2). It enters the orbit through the inferior orbital fissure and gives off the zygomaticotemporal and zygomaticofacial branches. The zygomaticotemporal nerve carries postganglionic parasympathetic fibers that originated from the pterygopalatine ganglion (after traveling via the Vidian nerve) and then joins the lacrimal nerve. These fibers are responsible for innervating the lacrimal gland, which produces tears. Therefore, an injury to nerve 'C' (zygomatic nerve) can interrupt the secretomotor pathway to the lacrimal gland, leading to a loss of tear production (loss of lacrimation).
• D – injury here causes loss of lacrimation (False): Structure 'D' is the infraorbital nerve, which is the direct continuation of the maxillary nerve after it exits the pterygopalatine fossa. The infraorbital nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin of the lower eyelid, cheek, upper lip, and side of the nose. It does not contain the parasympathetic secretomotor fibers for the lacrimal gland. The fibers that supply the lacrimal gland are carried by the zygomatic nerve, not the infraorbital nerve. Therefore, an injury to nerve 'D' would primarily result in sensory loss to the regions it supplies, not a loss of lacrimation.

questions.text: If the Percentage of thymine residues in DNA is 28%. What is the percentage of Guanine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

22%

Explanation: Adenine pairs with Thymine, so Adenine+Thymine = 56%

Guanine Always pair with Cytosine. So Guanine+Cytosine is 100-56= 44%

Hence Guanine = 44/2= 22%.

questions.text: A 42 year old man comes to the physician for a routine check-up. Serum studies shows a Glucose Concentration of 92 mg/dl and Homocysteine concentration of 24 micromol/L. (N=5-15). questions.solution:

Methionine

Explanation: Methionine is the amino acid directly involved in Homocysteine metabolism. Homocysteine can be remethylated to Methionine in a reaction that requires Methionine Synthase that depends on the coenzymes Folate and Vitamin-B12. Therefore, a deficiency in Methionine or cofactors like folate and Vitamin-B12 can lead to elevated Homocysteine levels.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman undergoes a colonoscopy to screen for colon cancer. Biopsy of a polyp removed during the procedure reveals epithelial cell metaplasia, with some cells progressing toward malignant transformation. A high-fiber diet is prescribed to generate more short-chain fatty acids. The figure below illustrates the concentration of protonated short-chain fatty acids on either side of a colonic epithelial cell membrane. If the concentration of fatty acids on the outside surface of the cell doubles, the rate of diffusion of the short-term fatty acids will change from 10 mg/h to which of the following rates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Absorption of protonated short-chain fatty acids into enterocytes occurs by simple diffusion. Fick lawstates that the net rate of diffusional flux (J) of a substance is proportional to its concentration difference (Δc). Doubling the concentration of protonated short-chain fatty acids outside of the enterocytes from 20 to 40 mg/L causes the concentration difference to increase by threefold from 10 to 30 mg/L. Therefore, the net rate of diffusion would increase from 10 to 30 mg/h. Short-chain fatty acids are released by the action of the colonic microflora on dietary fiber. These short-chain fatty acids promote survival of healthy colonic epithelium while inducing apoptosis in epithelial cells progressing toward malignant transformation.

choices.text: Increasing the permeability of the membrane to potassium

questions.text: 5-day-old infant starts having brief tonic–clonic seizures throughout the day. His neurological function in between seizures is normal, and he has no other medical or neurological problems. The history reveals no readily apparent causes for the seizures, though the mother recalled that her first baby also developed seizures shortly after birth that only lasted for 2 weeks, with no subsequent episodes or developmental problems. Genetic analysis revealed a mutation of voltage-gated K+ channels consistent with a diagnosis of benign familial neonatal seizures. Which of the following would cause an immediate reduction in the amount of potassium leaking out of a cell?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The amount of potassium moving out of the cell depends on its membrane potential, its concentration gradient, and its membrane conductance. According to the Nernst equation, the electrical gradient for K+ is inward and the concentration gradient is outward. Hyperpolarizing the membrane makes the inside of the cell more negative and therefore makes it more difficult for potassium to flow out of the cell. Answer (a) is incorrect because decreasing the extracellular potassium concentration would increase the flow of potassium out of the cell, as would increasing the permeability of the membrane to potassium (answer d). Decreasing the activity of the sodium–potassium pump (answer e) has no immediate effect on potassium efflux, but ultimately results in depolarization of the membrane, resulting in an increased flow of potassium out of the cell. Altering the extracellular sodium concentration (answer b) has no immediate effect on the flow of potassium across the membrane. Seizures are paroxysmal disturbances in cerebral function caused by an abnormal synchronous discharge of cortical neurons. The epilepsies are a group of disorders characterized by recurrent seizures. Benign familial neonatal seizures constitute a rare type of idiopathic epilepsy linked to autosomal dominant mutations of voltage-gated K+ channels.

questions.text: 45-year-old female patient has an annual exam. She weighs 60 kg. She complains of fatigue. Her hematocrit is 35%. What is the patient’s estimated blood volume in liters?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) To calculate blood volume from a person’s weight and hematocrit, plasma volume must be calculated first. Plasma volume is approximately 5% of the total body weight (plasma volume = 60 kg × 0.05 = 3 L). Next, blood volume is calculated using plasma volume and hematocrit. Blood volume = (Plasma volume) / (1 – hematocrit) = (3 L)/(1 – 0.35) = 3 L/0.65 = 4.6 L.

choices.text: Can be hypotonic or hypertonic depending on whether the gland is stimulated or unstimulated.

questions.text: With respect to plasma saliva is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The primary secretion of saliva from the acini is isotonic but the composition of the saliva is modified as it flows from the acini out into ducts that eventually coalesce and deliver the saliva into the mouth. Na+ and Cl− are extracted and K+ and bicarbonate are added. Because the ducts are relatively impermeable to water, the loss of NaCl renders the saliva hypotonic, particularly at low secretion rates. As the rate of secretion increases, there is less time for NaCl to be extracted and the tonicity of the saliva rises, but it always stays somewhat hypotonic with respect to plasma.

questions.text: 1- year-old male is found to have high blood pressure, normal genitalia on physical examination, low serum aldosterone and high serum testosterone. Which of the following is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This patient is most likely suffering from congenital 11 β-hydroxylase deficiency. 11- β- hydroxylase deficiency leads to the inability to synthesize aldosterone with a buildup of the mineralocorticoid 11-deoxycorticosterone.

11- β hydroxylase deficiency is a form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. The enzyme responsible for converting 11-deoxycorticosterone into aldosterone and 11-deoxycortisol into cortisol. A deficiency results in low levels of cortisol and high levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone which has mineralocorticoid activity and is responsible for the hypertension seen in this patient. Furthermore, sex hormones such as testosterone become elevated as cortisol precursors are diverted toward the androgen synthesis pathway. Male patients with 11-hydroxylase deficiency consequently have normal genitalia at birth, while females have ambiguous genitalia.

Incorrect answers:

Answer A: 17-hydroxylase deficiency presents in a male with ambiguous genitalia due to decreased production of testosterone.

Answer B: 21-hydroxylase deficiency presents with low levels of serum mineralocorticoids and low blood pressure. Testosterone would also be elevated in this case.

Answer C: This patient is suffering from a deficiency of 11-hydroxylase and, thus, we would not expect 11-hydroxylase to be elevated.

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct description of connections involving cerebellar neurons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Granule cells are the only excitatory neuron in the cerebellum. They secrete glutamate which excites the basket cells and stellate cells. Basket and stellate are inhibitory, and they inhibit the Purkinje cells.

questions.text: During a physiology experiment, a muscle is extracted and suspended in a physiologic solution. The muscle contracts when directly stimulated with an electrode, but it does not contract spontaneously. It continues to contract upon stimulation after being treated with a drug that antagonizes myosin light chain kinase activity, and after it is placed in new salt solution that is calcium-free. Based on the experimental data provided, what type of muscle tissue is most likely being tested?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The muscle tissue being tested contracts when stimulated with an electrode, even in the absence of extracellular calcium, which indicates skeletal muscle tissue. (A) Cardiac muscle has automaticity, which allows the muscle to spontaneously contract without any electrical or hormonal stimuli. It also requires extracellular calcium influx through the dihydropyridine receptor (DHP) to open the ryanodine receptors (RyR) on the sarcoplasmic reticulum for substantial cytoplasmic calcium increases (calcium-induced calcium release). Therefore, because the experimental muscle tissue does not contract spontaneously and because it does contract in the absence of calcium, cardiac muscle tissue is excluded. (B, D) Smooth muscle tissue requires phosphorylation of myosin light chain (MLC) by myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) for contraction to occur. Because the experimental muscle tissue continues to contract when antagonized by a drug that blocks MLCK, this excludes smooth muscle tissue.

questions.text: 68-year-old woman with a recent history of urinary tract infections presents with pain on her side and back, justifying renal function tests. As part of it, which of the following is tested by the creatinine clearance test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Renal clearance is the kidneys’ ability to clear a given substance (in this case creatinine) completely from a given volume of plasma per unit time (in this case per minute) as it passes through the renal vasculature. Creatinine clearance is used clinically to estimate glomerular filtration rate.

questions.text: In the spirometry trace shown, which label correctly identifies the inspiratory reserve volume and which label correctly identifies the expiratory reserve volume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV):
    The maximum volume of air that can be inspired after a normal tidal inspiration.
    → On the graph, label A represents the extra inspiratory volume above the normal tidal volume → this is IRV.
  • Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV):
    The maximum volume of air that can be expired after a normal tidal expiration.
    → On the graph, label E represents the extra expiratory volume below the normal tidal volume → this is ERV.

questions.text: A 5 year old child presents with Low-Grade fever for 6 days and on Examination has enlarged cervical Lymph nodes with a Palpable Spleen . He was given Ampicillin followed by development by extensive rash all over the body. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Infectious Mononucleosis

Explanation: Infectious Mononucleosis also known as Glandular fever is caused by Ebstein-Bar Virus . It presents typically in young population and spreads through Saliva. The two main clinical presentations are 1.Gradual onset of Low-Grade fever 2. Cervical Lymphadenopathy. Splenomegaly is also seen in 2nd-3rd weeks.

The key word in the question is the development of rash after the administration of Ampicillin. The morbilliform rash on the arms and trunk develops both in Patients exposed to penicillin derivatives and those who are not exposed to Penicillin. Atypical Lymphocytosis is the blood picture with deranged LFT. Most cases are Self-Limited.

CK7-, CK20-

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with long hands and Feet and a Protruding Jaw. Which of the genes will be implicated in this scenario?

questions.text: A newborn baby presented with profuse bleeding from the umbilical stump after birth. Rest of the examination, APTT and PT are within normal limits. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Glanzmann`s Thrombasthenia

Explanation: Presence of normal APTT and PT rules out any clotting Factor Deficiency. So options like Factor X deficiency, Factor XIII deficiency and Hemophilia A have been ruled out. 

Glanzmann`s Thrombasthenia is an Autosomal Recessive inherited defect in Gp II-b-III where there will be Aggregation defect. Ristocetin Agglutination Test will be normal or Positive , Platelet count will be normal and Platelet morphology will be normal. 

Delayed Separation of the Umbilical Stump beyond 4 weeks is a characteristic finding seen in Factor XIII deficiency.

questions.text: Wire Loop lesions are often characteristic for the which class of lupus Nephritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Diffuse Proliferative Glomerulonephritis(Class-IV)

Explanation: Diffuse Lupus Glomerulonephritis (Class-IV) is the most common and severe form of Lupus Nephritis. In class-IV , more than 50% of Glomeruli are affected.  Involved Glomeruli show proliferation of Endothelial, Mesangial and Epithelial cells with the latter producing cellular crescents that fill Bowman`s space. Sub-endothelial immune complex deposits may create a circumferential thickening of the capillary wall forming “wall loop” structures on light Microscopy.   

-Lesions may progress to scarring of glomeruli. Patients with diffuse Glomerulonephritis are usually symptomatic, showing hematuria as well as Proteinuria. Hypertension and mild to severe renal insufficiency are also common.

1.Most common sporadic Tumor

2.Associated with loss of Short arm of chromosome 3

3. Arises from the distal Convoluted Tubule

4. Cells show Intracellular Accumulation of Glycogen and Fat.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation: Clear cell Carcinoma is the most common Sporadic Renal Cell Cancer and shows intra-cellular accumulation of Glycogen and Fat.

-Arises from the Proximal Tubular Epithelium 

-Most of the cases are Sporadic , but can also occur either in Familial forms or in association with Von-Hippel Lindau Disease. Associated with loss of short arm of chromosome 3p.

choices.text: Monoclonal plasma cells in the bone marrow

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for diagnosis of multiple myeloma?

For diagnosis of multiple myeloma the following criteria should be met

1. Bone marrow monoclonal plasma cells >10% Or plasmacytoma on tissue biopsy

AND

2. Anyone of the following evidence of end organ damage (CRAB criteria)

C →Hypercalcemia

R→Renal insufficiency

A→Anemia

B→Bone lesions

choices.text: Mantle Zone Lymphoma: CD5+, CD10-, CD23-
Marginal Zone Lymphoma: CD5-, CD10- , CD23+

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Marginal Zonal Lymphoma: CD5-,CD10-,CD23+

Explanation:

CD10 & CD23 are the markers of Follicular centre or Germinal centre. So for Follicular Lymphoma it will be CD5-, CD10+, CD23+.

CD5 is the marker of Mantle Zone. So for Mantle Zone it wll be CD5+,CD10-,CD23-

For Marginal Zone Lymphoma it will be CD5-, CD10-,CD23-.

For CLL/SLL it is CD5+, CD10-, CD23+.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Condyloma acuminata

This is a classical image of genital warts. It occurs due to HPV 6,11 virus. It is a low-risk virus, do not predispose the patient to develop carcinoma. There are other non-genital HPV infections which cause Verruca plana (HPV 3,10), Verruca Vulgaris (HPV 2,5)

questions.text:
Consider the causes of Alopecia, which among the following are the causes of Scarring Alopecia?

1.	Lichen Planus

2.	Sarcoidosis

3.	Tinea Capitis

4.	Secondary Syphilis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: Alopecia can be classified into:

A)	Non-Scarring Alopecia

B)	Scarring Alopecia

Causes of Non-Scarring Alopecia:

Types : A) Patchy : Alopecia Areata
                                 Trichotillomania
                                 Tinea Capitis (Non-Inflammatory)
                                 Secondary Syphilis 

B)Diffuse: Anagen Effluvium and Telogen Effluvium

C)Patterned : Androgenetic Alopecia

D) Systemic: SLE, Thyroid Dysfunction
    
Causes of Scarring Alopecia: 

1.	Papulo-squamous Disease: Lichen Planus

2.	Connective Tissue Diseases: DLE, Discoid Lesions of SLE, Linear Morphea

3.	Tinea Capitis (Inflammatory): Favus , Kerion

4.	Granulomatous Disorders: Sarcoidosis

5.	Inflammatory Diseases : Folliculitis Decalvans, Dissecting Cellulitis of Scalp

6.	Idiopathic : Disorder of Exclusion : Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text: A 28 year old Man presented to General Practitioner with Facial-Sparing Maculopapular Rash with Involvement of Palms & Soles. He also complains of a Painless, Solitary Ulcer on his penis. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Syphilis 

Painless Ulcers seen in : 1) Syphilis                                       Painful ulcers seen in: 1) Chancroid
                                            2) Donovanosis                                                                       2) Herpes 
                                            3) LGV 

Single Painless Ulcer is Diagnostic of Primary Syphilis. Syphilitic Ulcer is also called Hard 

Chancre/Hunterian Chancre.

Features are: 1) Single Ulcer
                        2) Clean Based
                        3) Non-Tender
                        4) Indurated
                        5) Does not Bleed on Touch 

Inguinal LNs: Bilaterally Enlarged, Non-tender, Non-Suppurative.

Secondary Syphilis: Develops after 4-8 weeks after healing of primary Chancre. The organism start 

Spreading Hematogenously from Genital Chancre and Inguinal nodes. 

-There will be Generalized Lymphadenopathy and characteristic Epitrochlear Group of Lymph nodes will be enlarged.

Skin lesions of Secondary Syphilis: A) Rash which will be Symmetric, non-pruritic, Polymorphic (All types of Skin lesions except Vesicles and Bullae). Site of this rash will be Palms & Soles. 

Cutaneous Lesions of Secondary Syphilis are not infectious as they do not have Enough Treponemas. Exceptions are Condyloma Lata`s & Mucous Patches which are highly infectious.  

B)Condyloma Lata

C) Mucous Patches

D) Snail Track Ulcer

E) Alopecia 

Syphilis d`emblee: It is Acquired through Blood Transfusion. There is no Primary Stage and directly presents with secondary Syphilis. 

Diagnosis: Non-Treponemal Tests (VDRL/RPR)

Tertiary Syphilis: A) Gummatous
                              B)Cardiovascular Syphilis
                              C) Neurosyphilis

questions.text: A 9 year old girl is brought with complaints of itchy lesions on his face for 7 days. On examination, multiple ruptured blisters with Honey-colored crusting are seen. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Non-Bullous Impetigo 

Explanation:  Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Non-Bullous Impetigo. 

-Non-Bullous Impetigo/Impetigo Contagiosa:

Etiology: Streptocooci and Staphylococci

Age Group: Children

Site: Perioral, Perinasal

Lesion: Golden Yellow or Honey Colored Crust

Complication: Post-Streptocoocal Glomerulonephritis due to Hypersensitivity Reaction. 

Bullous Impetigo /Pemphigus Neonatorum :

Etiology : Staphylocoocus Aureus 

Toxin: Epidermolytic Toxin liberated by Staphlyococcus Aureus

Lesion: Hypopyon Sign (The pus gravitates to the lower half of Bulla).

Crust: Varnish Crust when the lesions resolve

Management: Topical Antibacterials ; 1.Fusidic Acid
                                                                   2. Mupirocin: Inhibit MRSA, therefore used in nasal carriers.

questions.text: A 51 year old female presented with Persistent oral lesions that are characterized by ill-defined, irregular margins with peripheral extensions and shedding of Epithelium as shown in the image below. The lesions are Painful and have recurrent. Histopathological examination reveals Suprabasal Acantholysis without signs of epidermal Necrosis or significant inflammatory Infiltrate. Direct Immunofluorescence shows intercellular deposits of IgG and C3 in the Epidermis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pemphigus Vulgaris Explanation: Given clinical History and image is suggestive of Pemphigus Vulgaris. Pemphigus Vulgaris and pemphigus Foliaceous are Intra-epidermal level of Split diseases.

It shows satellitism phenomenon with Staphylococcus Aureus

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, neck rigidity. On CSF examination it showed low Glucose, High Protein and polymorphs. Gram Stain showed Pleomorphic Gram-Negative Bacilli. Which of the following is true for the Probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It shows satellitism phenomenon with Staphylococcus Aureus

Explanation: Low Glucose, High Protein, Predominance of Polymorphs in the CSF is suggestive of Pyogenic Meningitis. 

-The description of”Pleomorphic Gram-negative Bacilli clinches the diagnosis as Hemophilus Influenzae serotype “b” notorious for causing Meningitis in Kids <2years of age.

-It shows the phenomenon of Satellitism on Blood Agar.

-It doesn`t grow on MacConkey Agar , is not sensitive to Bacitracin

questions.text: A 19 year old male presented with complains of vomiting. He had pastries from the restaurant 4 hours ago. Which enterotoxin cannot be involved in this case of Food Poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Type F

Explanation: Enterotoxin F is not associated with Food Poisoning. 

Staphylococcal Enterotoxin-A is the most common cause of staphylococcal Food poisoning worldwide, but the involvement of other classical Staphylococcal Enterotoxin has also been demonstrated.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses can cause more severe disease with complications following re-infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dengue Virus 

Explanation: After an attack of dengue, antibodies are formed that are specific for that serotype.

On Subsequent Infection with a different Serotype, the antibodies bind to the virus and not only fail to neutralize it but actually enhance its ability to infect monocytes.

The Fc portion of the virus-bound immunoglobulin (Ig) molecules attaches to Fc Receptors on monocytes and entry into the cell by this route increases the efficiency of infection.

Infection of increased numbers of monocytes results in an increased release of cytokines into the circulation and this leads to vascular damage, shock and hemorrhage.

questions.text: The Epstein-Barr Virus interacts with B-cells via which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

CD-21

Explanation: B-cells are the principal targets of EBV infection, primarily due to their expression of CD21, the major receptor for the virus.

Rapid antigen Test to detect spike Proteins

questions.text: Which of the following methods cannot detect SARS CoV-2 ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Southern Blotting 

Explanation: SARS-CoV-2 can be detected by all except Southern Blotting as there is not enough DNA in collected sample to obtain a pattern in Gel Electrophoresis. (SARS CoV-2 is a RNA virus).

questions.text: Which micro-organism is not included in Bio-safety Level III?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ebola

Explanation: 

Bio-safety Level III is defined as microbes which cause serious or potentially lethal disease. Pose high Hazards to Laboratorians and environment. 

Examples are : Mycobacterium Tuberculosis, Bacillus Anthracis, Francisella Tularemia, Yersinia Pestis, Chlamydia Psittaci, Coxiella Burnetti, Salmonella typhi, Shigella Dysentery Type 1, Burkholderia Pseudomallei, Japanese Encephalitis Virus 

-Ebola comes under BSL-IV.

questions.text: Which mechanism allows for the transfer of genetic material via Bacteriophages in Bacterial Genetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Transduction

Explanation: Gene transfer which occurs through Transduction and Lysogenic conversion occurs via Bacteriophages 

Transduction is the transfer of bacterial genes from one bacterium to another via Bacteriophages. It is the most common Mechanism. 

Transformation: Uptake of DNA from the environment independent of bacteriophages. 

Conjugation: Direct transfer of DNA from one bacterium to another through direct contact, independent of Bacteriophages. Most common method of Multi-drug resistance.

questions.text: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Toxoplasmosis 

Explanation: Sabin Feldman Dye Test is a Gold Standard test for diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis. Uses IgG class of Antibody and appears 2-3 weeks after infection, peak around 6-8 weeks and then they taper and persist Lifelong.

questions.text: Young boy is brought to the OPD with history of recurrent Pneumonia and Eczema. Peripheral smear shows Thrombocytopenia and small Platelets. Which class of antibody will be deficient?
questions.solution:

IgM

Explanation: Given clinical history is suggestive of Wiskott -Aldrich Syndrome.
Wiskott -Aldrich syndrome is characterized by triad of :

A)Eczema

B)Recurrent Infections

C) Thrombocytopenia

 In Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, IgM levels are reduced , IgE and IgA are elevated and IgG is normal.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the given image?

In Loa-Loa : Nuclei upto tail tip , Sheathed

questions.text: A 25 year old teacher had recent history of upper Respiratory Tract Infection. He presents to the General Practitioner with Headache. In detailed History of Headache he tells that it comes upon waking up, worsens during mid-day and improves as the day progresses. Which sinus shows this feature?

Frontal Sinusitis

Explanation: Headache in Frontal Sinusitis is called Early Morning /Office/Periodic Headache. It shows characteristic Periodicity. Increases on waking up, worsens during Mid-day and improves as the day progresses.

questions.text: Dingman`s classification is used for which fractures?
questions.solution:

Mandibular Fractures

Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis

questions.text: A 70 Year old man has undergone Total Thyroidectomy for Papillary thyroid Cancer and has been shifted to the Post operative ward for stridor but his voice was normal. What is the likely cause for the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bilateral Abductor Palsy

Explanation: Given clinical history is suggestive of Bilateral Adductor Palsy.  In Bilateral Abductor Palsy both the cords lie in Median or Para-median Position. In Bilateral Adductor Palsy:

-Speech: Normal

-Respiration: Stridor, may lead to death if untreated

-Aspiration: Absent

-Management: Tracheostomy followed by Lateralization of vocal cord

Normal voice is seen only in  Bilateral Abductor Palsy.

questions.text: Which is the narrowest portion of the Middle Ear Cavity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mesotympanum

Explanation: Narrowest portion of the middle ear cavity is Mesotympanum.

Middle Ear is divided into 3 parts by two lines.

Two lines drawn at the upper and lower border of Pars Tensa.

Epitympanum- 6mm

Mesotympanum- 2mm

Hypotympanum-4mm

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in High-Frequency or Down-sloping Audiogram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Meniere`s Disease

-High Frequency (Down-sloping) Audiogram:

1)Presbycusis

2) Ototoxicity

3) Noise Trauma

-Mid-Frequency Audiogram

1) Congenital SNHL

Compound hypermetropic astigmatism against the rule

questions.text: After completion of retinoscopy of right eye of a child, it was noted that the vertical axis power was +4 dioptres and horizontal axis was + 6 dioptres. What will be the refractive error for the right eye of the child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Both axis have plus power – means both axis rays are focused behind retina (compound hypermetropic astigmatism). The vertical axis is more myopic, so its steeper – with the rule astigmatism.

questions.text: A worker presented with sudden onset of vision loss with pain and redness after an explosion in metal industry where he works.  On examination, the doctor noted vision to be only Perception of light present. There was scleral perforation in nasal part of eye with uveal tissue show.  What is not done in such a scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Indications of removal of IOFB

• If injury acute (e.g. 24–48 hours)

• If patient presents much later (e.g. 7 days), removal is indicated if:

– Endophthalmitis is present

– IOFB is toxic (copper, iron)

– IOFB is organic

– Associated vitreous hemorrhage

– IOFB is impacted onto retina

questions.text:
Select the true statements regarding the following condition 

‘ A condition in which can be congenital or acquired condition where eyelashes arise from the meibomian glands on the posterior lamella of the eyelid’

2.    Caused due to metaplasia of Meibomian gland

3.    This can be caused by prostaglandin analogue

4.    Cornea should be checked for any punctate defects

Correct Answer (B)

Metaplasia: Extra row of hair follicle, caused by metaplasia of meibomian gland

It can rub onto cornea, so ornea be checked for any punctate defects
Prostaglandin analogue can cause hypertrichosis

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the given gaze positions of a patient who presented with c/o diplopia ?

Left eye ptosis, down and out eye in primary position suggestd 3rd nerve palsy.

There is limitation of all movements except of SO and LR

questions.text: A 24 yr old male patient presents to Ophthalmology OPD with c/o metamorphopsia. Fundoscopy showed a dull foveal relex. Angiography images is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis ?

Angiography showing central hyperfluoroscence due to pooling of dye in subretinal space Suggestive of central serous retinopathy

questions.text: A 55-year old man complaints of glare in eye while driving his car in the night. His best corrected vision 6/12. He had umdergone cataract surgery. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:

Most common complication of cataract surgery is post capsular opacification of lens, known as after cataract. Treatment is laser capsulotomy by Nd Yag

choices.text: Pupil reacts to light and near object
Pupil reacts to light but not to near object
Pupil does not react to light and near object
Pupil does not react to light but reacts to near object

questions.text: In a patient of 3rd nerve palsy, what is seen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

3rd nerve is efferent of both light and near reflex

Explanation:
• The oculomotor nerve (3rd cranial nerve) carries:
o Somatic efferents to extraocular muscles (except LR6, SO4).
o Parasympathetic fibers to the sphincter pupillae (for light reflex) and ciliary muscles (for accommodation reflex).
• In 3rd nerve palsy:
o Eye is deviated "down and out" due to unopposed action of LR6 and SO4.
o Ptosis occurs due to paralysis of levator palpebrae superioris.
o Mydriasis (dilated pupil) occurs because parasympathetic fibers to sphincter pupillae are lost.
o Since parasympathetic supply is lost → no pupillary constriction to light or to near response (accommodation).

questions.text: All are the things to be noted in a patient of congenital glaucoma of 1 year old during examination except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Goldmann is done on slit lamp and cannot be done in a 2 year old child

Corneal diameter are noted as eyeball and cornea size increases in a child with congenital glaucoma

questions.text:
What will be the diagnosis of given Acid-Base Disorder?

Ph=7.44

HCO3-: 34

Pco2: 40
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:

Ph=7.44 → Increased ph → Alkalosis

HCo3-=34 → Increased → Primary Metabolic defect

So it is Metabolic Alkalosis.

Compensation for Metabolic Alkalosis : (0.9*Pts HCO) + 16

Expected Increase in PCO2= 47 mm

But Report shows PaCO2 of 40mm – Hence Uncompensated.

questions.text: A 28-year old Female presents with amenorrhea and Galactorrhea. She denies any recent pregnancy or breastfeeding. Her Serum Prolactin is markedly elevated (greater than 220mg/dl). MRI of the Sella turcica reveals a 1.5cm pituitary mass consistent with a Prolactinoma. What is the first-line treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dopamine Agonists

Explanation:  This is Pituitary Macroadenoma(>1cm). The first line treatment for a patient with a prolactinoma, like the one in scenario, is Dopamine Agonists. Therefore, Dopamine Agonists works effectively to reduce the size of the Prolactinoma . Surgical Indications include Pressure effect, Pituitary Apoplexy, Resistance to dopa agonists, Visual effects Sx: Trans-sphenoidal Resection

questions.text: A 50 year-old woman presents with weakness over the past 1 week. She has history of Diarrhea 4 weeks back. On examination, muscle bulk is normal, motor strength is 2/5 in lower limbs. Ankle and knee deep tendon reflexes are absent. The CSF examination shows Cyto-Albumin dissociation. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Guillain Barre syndrome

Explanation: GBS most commonly occurs after an attack of Diarrhea/Dysentry caused by most commonly Campylobacter Jejuni. There is Molecular Mimicry i.e. sharing of homologous epitopes between micro-organisms and Liposaccharides and nerve Gangliosides , misdirects the antibodies host peripheral nerves.
Clinical Features:

-Acute inflammatory Polyradiculoneuropathy : Radicular pain with Tingling, numbness etc 2-3 days prior to weakness.

-B/L proximal followed by distal weakness which starts in Lower limb - then Upper Limb- Brain Stem i..e Ascending Symmetrical Weakness that evolves over hours to few days.

Areflexia, Flaccidity due to Polyradiculoneuropathy 

-ANS involvement , Bowel/Bladder symptoms may be seen.

On CSF analysis, there will be Albumin-cytological dissociation: High concentration of Protein in CSF, with fewer than 10 cells per cubic millimeter

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely an extrahepatic manifestations seen in patients with Hepatitis C infection?

Membranous Nephropathy

Explanation: Hepatitis C extra-hepatic Manifestations:

-Essential Mixed Cryoglobulinemia

-Membranous-proliferative Glomerulonephritis

-Lichen Planus

-Porphyria Cutanea Tarda

-Autoimmune Hepatitis 

-Diabetes Mellitus

Hepatitis-B extra-hepatic Manifestations:

-Membranous Nephropathy

-Polyarteritis Nodosa

-Erythema Multiforme

-Urticaria

-Serum Sickness

questions.text: A 65 year old smoker presents to the casualty with High-Grade fever, shortness of breath, Diarrhea and confusion. Gram-staining of the sputum revealed Neutrophilia with no organisms. Lab values shows: Na+: 114mEq/l. X-ray shows Multi-lobar infiltrates. What will be the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Legionella

Explanation: Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Legionella Infection. 

-Spread through Contaminated Water.

-High-Grade Fever, Cough

Extra-Pulmonary Features are: Associated Diarrhea, Confusion, Hyponatremia, Headache, Altered LFTs, Encephalopathy.

-Poor Response to Beta-Lactams

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In Acute Myeloid Leukemia translocations seen will be t(8:21) , t(15:17), t(16:16)

In follicular Lymphoma & DLBCL translocations seen will be t(14:18)

In Mantle Zone lymphoma:     t(11:14)

In Marginal Zone Lymphoma: t(11:18)

choices.text: Start ART and then ATT after 1 week
Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks
Start ART and then ATT after 2 weeks

questions.text: Patient diagnosed with HIV presented to the OPD with Fever, Night sweat, Cough and hemoptysis. His sputum showed Acid-Fast Bacilli. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks

Explanation: In a patient with HIV and TB, start with ATT first and then ART after 2weeks to 2 months (when ATT is tolerated). This is done in order to avoid Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome.  
Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome(IRIS): Patients with HIV-related TB may experience a temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ATT. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART and ATT. It is characterized by High fever, lymphadenopathy, expanding intra-thoracic lesions and worsening of chest X-ray findings. Rx: Prednisolone 1-2mg/kg

questions.text: Patient presented with history of fever, headache and Ataxia. Imaging shows basal Exudates and Dilated Ventricles. Which of this findings seen in CSF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lymphocytosis, Low Glucose, High protein

Explanation: Given clinical History and image is suggestive of Tuberculous Meningitis. CSF shows Lymphocytosis, Low Glucose and High protein. If the CSF is allowed to stand, spider`s web clot or cobweb coagulum may be formed due to high level of protein.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman develops acute onset of fever, malaise and cough. On examination uveitis, Bilateral parotid Enlargement and 7th Cranial nerve Palsy are seen. Chest is clear on Auscultation. The chest X-ray reveals bilateral Hilar Lymphadenopathy and a left Para-tracheal Lymph node. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Heerfordt`s Syndrome

Explanation: Given clinical history is suggestive of Sarcoidosis. 

Phenotypes of Sarcoidosis:

A)Lofgren Syndrome: Erythema Nodosum + Arthritis + Lymph Node Enlargement  

B) Uveo-parotid fever/Heerfordt`s Syndrome: Fever+ Uveitis + Parotitis + 7th Cranial Nerve Palsy

C)Lupus pernio

Ix: Gallium Scan: Increased uptake of Gallium by involved organs

-Increased uptake of dye in Lacrimal and Parotid Gland---- Panda Sign

-Increased uptake of dye in Bilateral Hilar Lymph nodes and Right Paratracheal Lymph nodes-- Lambda`s sign

IOC: Biopsy which shows non-caseating Granulomas

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac biomarkers rise earliest in myocardial injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ischemia Modified Albumin

Explanation:

CK-MB : Rise in 3-4 hours

Heart Fatty Acid Binding Protein: Rise in 1.5 hours

Ischemia Modified Albumin : Rise in minutes

Troponin-T : Rise in 2-4hours

questions.text: Which of the following is not the feature of Pre-Renal AKI ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) FeNa > 1% Explanation: Features of Pre-Renal AKI : Urine RM : Normal -S.Urea/S.Creatinine : >20 -Urine Na+ : < 20 -Urine Ph : Acidic -Urine Specific Gravity : 1.020-1.030 -Urine Creatinine/Plasma Creatinine: > 40 -Urine Osmolality : 700-800mosm/L -FeNa: < 1 (Best Criteria) : Urinary Na *Plasma Creatinine/ Urinary Creatinine * Plasma Na

questions.text: What is the inference of the given ECG ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mobitz type 1 Av block

Explanation: Given ECG is suggestive of Mobitz type-1 AV block also called Wenckebach Phenomenon. It is characterized by a progressive lengthening of the PR interval in successful beats until one P wave is not followed by QRS complexes (see in lead II).

In Mobitz type -II heart block, PR interval is constant.

questions.text: Which Anti-Diabetic medication is contraindicated in patients of MEN-2 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Liraglutide

Explanation: GLP-1 analogues are contra-indicated in patients suffering from Medullary thyroid cancer or family history of medullary thyroid cancer or MEN-2 syndrome. Issued with Black box Warning.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Barter-Schwartz criteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Serum Osmolality > urine Osmolality

Explanation: Barter Schwartz criteria is used in SIADH.

1.Urine Osmolality> Serum Osmolality

2.Low Serum Osmolality

3. Clinically Euvolemic

4. Urinary Na+>20 meq/L

5.Absence of Pituitary, Renal, Thyroid and Liver disease

6. SIADH patients never come with polyuria.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Nazer`s Prognostic Index?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

ALT

Explanation: Nazer`s Prognostic Index is used for prognosis of Wilson`s Disease. It includes:

-AST

questions.text: A patient working in the drilling industry presented with complains of Pain in the hand and fingers turning Pale on dipping in cold water. On examination his hands are seen as follows. What is the condition patient is suffering from?

This condition is characterized by vasospasm of the small arteries in response to cold or emotional stress, resulting in reduced blood flow to the extremities, such as the fingers causing Pain and pallor. People working in industries like drilling, where they are exposed to cold temperatures, may be at a higher risk of Developing Raynaud`s Phenomenon.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset Perineal Pain. On examination, foul-smelling Discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: Given clinical history is of Fournier`s Gangrene. It is mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection. 

Fournier`s Gangrene is a polymicrobial infection and a type of Necrotizing Fasciitis of the Perineum, External Genitalia and Perianal Region. Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as HIV, Alcoholism and Diabetes. A mixed infection of the aerobic and Anaerobic bacteria- Fulminating Inflammation of Subcutaneous Tissues-- Obliterative Arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal Pain Gangrene

-Clinical Features of Fournier Gangrene are scrotal Pain, Fever, Prostration and pallor. Cellulitis spreads rapidly and may be associated with eschars, necrosis , flaking skin and crepitus. The testis is usually not affected.

questions.text: Which intravenous Anesthetic agent has highest incidence of Nausea and Vomitting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Etomidate

Explanation: Etomidate has highest incidence of Post-operative Nausea and vomiting out of the given options.

• Etomidate is an IV anesthetic agent often used for induction because it maintains hemodynamic stability (minimal effect on heart rate and blood pressure).
• However, its major drawback is a high incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) compared to other agents.
• Other disadvantages include pain on injection, myoclonus, and adrenal suppression (inhibition of 11β-hydroxylase).
• Therefore, among IV anesthetics, etomidate is most emetogenic.

choices.text: Binding to sodium channels and causing their inactivation

questions.text: Mechanism of Action of local anaesthetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Local anesthetics bind a specific region of the α subunit and inhibit voltage-gated Na channels, preventing channel activation and inhibiting the Na influx associated with membrane depolarization.

•	With increasing local anesthetic concentrations, an increasing fraction of the Na channels in the membrane bind a local anesthetic molecule and cannot conduct Na ions as consequence, impulse conduction slows, the rate of rise and the magnitude of the action potential decrease, and the threshold for excitation and impulse conduction increases progressively.

•	At high enough local anesthetic concentrations and with a sufficient fraction of local anesthetic-bound Na channels, an action potential can no longer be generated, and impulse propagation is abolished.

•	Local anesthetics have a greater affinity for the channel in the open or inactivated state than in the resting state. (AIIMSQ)

•	Local anesthetic binding to Na channels does not alter the resting membrane potential. (NEETQ)

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. The patient has a past medical history of asthma on regular treatment with last exacerbation a month back. Rest all investigations are normal. Standard induction is done with propofol and fentanyl with vecuronium as muscle relaxant and cuffed endotracheal tube is inserted and confirmed in position using a capnography trace on the monitor. Shortly after the commencement of the surgery, the ventilator suddenly start showing alarm of increased peak airway pressures and the capnography waveform changes to image A. the anaesthesiologist immediately identifies the problem and intervenes and after 10 mins the capnograph changes to image B. which of the following is true about the intervention by the anesthesiologist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intraoperative bronchospasm

•	Bronchospasm is a reversible reflex spasm of the smooth muscle in the bronchi.

•	Bronchospasm is vagally mediated and caused by histamine, or one of many noxious stimuli, including cold air, inhaled irritants, and instrumentation (eg, tracheal intubation, surgical stimulation in light planes of anesthesia).

•	Bronchospasm is mediated by vagal afferents which result in an increase in cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP).

•	It is more common in asthmatics.

Bronchospasm: Manifestations

•	Rapidly increasing peak inspiratory pressure (plateau pressure unchanged)

•	Wheezing

•	Slowly increasing wave on the capnograph ( shark fin appearance)

•	Decreasing exhaled tidal volumes

Bronchospasm: Acute Treatment

1) Deepen anesthetic – increase volatile anesthetic concentration 

All volatile anesthetic agents are bronchodilators

Propofol or ketamine can be used to deepen the plane as well.

Ketamine has additional Broncho dilating effect

2) Consider alternative causes of high airway pressures eg. kinked tube, endobronchial intubation, etc.

3) Inhaled β2 -agonists – delivered to the inspiratory limb of the circuit through a metered dose inhaler or nebulized. If the severity of bronchospasm prohibits delivery of inhaled beta agonists, consider infusions of IV agonists such as terbutaline or epinephrine.

4) Consider administering intravenous steroids

The definition of grievous hurt is given under Section 320 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). It includes eight specific kinds of injuries considered severe due to their permanent nature or serious impairment.
These include:
1. Emasculation (permanent loss of masculine power).
2. Permanent privation of sight of either eye.
3. Permanent privation of hearing of either ear.
4. Privation of any member or joint.
5. Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
6. Permanent disfiguration of head or face.
7. Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.
8. Any hurt which endangers life, or which causes the victim to be in severe bodily pain or unable to follow ordinary pursuits for 20 days.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is unresponsive, not breathing, and pulseless. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is being performed. The cardiac monitor reading is shown below. Which of the following interventions should be performed next?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

• Defibrillate with 2 J/kg. (Correct): According to the Pediatric Advanced Life Support (PALS) guidelines, the definitive treatment for pVT is immediate defibrillation. The recommended initial energy dose for defibrillation in children is 2 joules per kilogram (J/kg). Defibrillation is an unsynchronized electrical shock that aims to depolarize a critical mass of myocardial cells simultaneously, allowing the natural pacemaker of the heart to resume control of the rhythm. Since this is a life-threatening, shockable rhythm, defibrillation must be performed as soon as the equipment is ready.
• Perform synchronized cardioversion with 1 J/kg. (Incorrect): Synchronized cardioversion is used for unstable patients with a pulse who have a tachyarrhythmia, such as supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) or ventricular tachycardia with a pulse. The patient in this scenario is pulseless, making synchronized cardioversion ineffective and inappropriate. The initial energy dose for synchronized cardioversion is also different (0.5-1 J/kg) from the defibrillation dose.
• Establish vascular access and administer epinephrine. (Incorrect): While establishing vascular access (intravenous or intraosseous) and administering epinephrine are crucial components of the pediatric cardiac arrest algorithm, they are secondary to defibrillation for shockable rhythms like pVT. The highest priority is to deliver an electrical shock as quickly as possible, as this is the only intervention that can terminate the arrhythmia and restore a perfusing rhythm. Medications like epinephrine are administered after the initial shock and in between subsequent shocks if the rhythm persists.
• Establish vascular access and insert an advanced airway. (Incorrect): Similar to option C, establishing vascular access and an advanced airway (e.g., endotracheal tube) are important steps in advanced life support. However, they should not delay the primary intervention for a shockable rhythm. High-quality chest compressions and early defibrillation take precedence. Interruptions to CPR should be minimized to allow for these procedures.

questions.text:
A newborn presents with purulent conjunctivitis and pneumonia. Baby has no fever and has normal activity. On the gram stain of the purulent discharge, there is no organism found. 
What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Chlamydia trachomatis

Gonococcal conjunctivitis begins with mild inflammation and a serosanguineous discharge. Within 24 hr, the discharge becomes thick and purulent, and tense edema of the eyelids with marked chemosis occurs. If proper treatment is delayed, the infection may spread to involve the deeper layers of the conjunctivae and the cornea. Complications include corneal ulceration and perforation, iridocyclitis, anterior synechiae, and rarely panophthalmitis.

questions.text:
A 30-week-gestation pregnant woman is seen at the obstetrician’s office for a febrile illness. Her symptoms include headache and joint pain. She has had routine prenatal care and no complications of pregnancy. Physical examination reveals the rash shown in figure.  She asks how this illness may affect her newborn.

Of the following, the MOST accurate response is that a likely sequela is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The most likely sequela for the newborn in the vignette is generalized edema. Maternal infection with parvovirus B19 is suggested by arthralgia and a lacy rash. Maternal infection can lead to fetal hydrops, isolated pleural or pericardial effusions in the fetus, intrauterine growth restriction, anemia, and fetal demise. Pregnant women with acute parvovirus B19 infection should be monitored closely; fetal infection is thought to occur in approximately 30% of cases. Fetal deaths have only been described with maternal infections in the first half of pregnancy; they are estimated to occur in 3% to 11% of maternal infections before 20 weeks’ gestation.

Parvovirus B19 infections are often asymptomatic. Clinical manifestations include erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease), characterized by a facial rash with a “slapped cheek” appearance that is followed by a symmetric, lacy or maculopapular, pruritic exanthem of the trunk and extremities

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Calcium normal and ALP normal

• Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by reduced bone mass and microarchitectural deterioration, leading to increased fracture risk.
• Importantly, it is a quantitative bone disorder (loss of bone mass) but bone mineralization is normal.
• Therefore, most routine blood investigations are normal:
o Serum calcium → Normal
o Serum phosphate → Normal
o Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) → Normal (unless there is a recent fracture, where it may rise transiently)
• Diagnosis is usually confirmed by DEXA scan (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry).

• A Colles’ fracture is a fracture of the distal radius, about 2–2.5 cm proximal to the wrist joint, with characteristic displacement patterns.
• The classic deformity is the “dinner fork deformity” due to:
o Dorsal displacement and tilt of the distal fragment

• Volar tilt (anterior tilt) is not seen in Colles’ fracture. Instead, there is a dorsal tilt.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in a whole body CT-scan protocol for trauma Patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation:

  • In polytrauma cases, a whole body CT (WBCT) scan is often performed as a part of initial assessment in emergency/trauma settings.
  • The standard WBCT protocol usually includes:
    • CT-Head → to detect intracranial hemorrhage, skull fractures.
    • CT-Cervical spine → to rule out cervical injuries.
    • CT-Chest → to detect rib fractures, pneumothorax, hemothorax, lung contusions, vascular injuries.
    • CT-Abdomen and pelvis → to detect solid organ injury (liver, spleen, kidneys), hemoperitoneum, retroperitoneal bleeding.
  • CT of the extremities (lower limb/upper limb) is not a routine part of the WBCT protocol. These are done selectively, if limb trauma is suspected clinically or on X-ray.

questions.text: A known HIV patient on retro viral therapy, developed pigmentation of palm and sole. what could be the drug responsible for this untoward adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Emticitabine causes palm and sole pigmentation

Zidovudine causes skin and nail pigmentation 

• Zidovudine (Incorrect): While zidovudine is an older antiretroviral drug known to cause hyperpigmentation, it typically affects the nails and oral mucosa more frequently. Although it can cause pigmentation on the skin, including the palms and soles, it is not the most common culprit for this specific pattern of symmetrical palmoplantar hyperpigmentation. The classic "zidovudine pigmentation" is often described as a blue-gray discoloration of the nails.
• Emtricitabine (Correct): Emtricitabine (FTC) is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) commonly used in modern antiretroviral therapy (ART) regimens. A well-documented but rare side effect of this drug, particularly in individuals with darker skin tones, is hyperpigmentation of the palms, soles, and sometimes the nails and face. The pigmentation is often diffuse and symmetrical, appearing as a darkening of the skin in the affected areas. This clinical presentation precisely matches the image provided, making Emtricitabine the most likely cause.
• Capecitabine (Incorrect): Capecitabine is a chemotherapy drug used to treat various cancers, not an antiretroviral. While it can cause a similar skin reaction known as hand-foot syndrome (palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia), this condition is characterized by redness, swelling, blistering, and peeling of the palms and soles, which can be quite painful. It is an inflammatory reaction, not typically a simple hyperpigmentation as shown in the image.
• Nevirapine (Incorrect): Nevirapine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) used in HIV treatment. Its most serious and well-known side effects are severe skin rashes, including Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), and hepatotoxicity (liver damage). While it can cause skin problems, it is not associated with the specific pattern of diffuse hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles.

Mavacamten is the direct myosin inhibitor useful HOCM

Molsidomine acting by relasing nitric oxide useful for prophylaxis of angina

Ibutilide is the class III antiarrhythmic agent approved for conversion of atrial fibrillation into normal sinus rhythm

Fenoldopam is the D1 agonist, useful for hypertensive emergency with renal impairment

questions.text: New Drug application is done after this phase of clinical trial
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • A New Drug Application (NDA) is submitted to the regulatory authority (e.g., USFDA, CDSCO in India) after successful completion of Phase 3 clinical trials.
  • Purpose of NDA: To request approval for marketing the drug for general use in the population, based on evidence of safety, efficacy, and quality.

Phases of Clinical Trials in brief:

  • Phase 1: Conducted in healthy volunteers (20–80). Purpose → assess safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics.
  • Phase 2: Conducted in patients (100–300). Purpose → evaluate efficacy and dose-ranging along with safety.
  • Phase 3: Conducted in larger patient populations (1,000–3,000). Purpose → confirm safety and efficacy, compare with standard treatment, and gather data for drug labeling. ➝ After this → NDA is filed.
  • Phase 4: Post-marketing surveillance → monitors long-term safety, rare adverse effects, new indications.

questions.text:
Find out the true statement 

A. Sotatercept approved for pulmonary arterial hypertension 

B. Resmetirom approved for NASH (Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis)

C. Trofinetide approved for Rett syndrome 

D. Fostamatinib approved for ITP
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sotatercept is a novel, first-in-class fusion protein composed of the extracellular domain of the human activin receptor type IIA fused to the Fc domain of human IgG1. Sotatercept acts as a ligand trap for members of the TGF-β superfamily, thus restoring balance between the growth-promoting activin growth differentiation factor pathway and the growth-inhibiting BMP pathway, approved for pulmonary arterial hypertension Resmetirom It is thyroid hormone receptor beta (NR1A2) agonist approved for NASH (Non alcoholic steatohepatitis) Trofinetide is thought to stimulate synaptic maturation and overcome the synaptic and neuronal immaturities that are characteristic of Rett syndrome pathophysiology. approved for Rett syndrome Fostamatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor medication for the treatment of chronic immune thrombocytopenia (ITP)

questions.text: A young patient on treatment with drugs for MDR tuberculosis presents with weight gain, cold intolerance and lethargy. On investigations, there was high levels of TSH and low levels of T3 and T4 in the blood. Which of the following is the likely drug responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anti TB drugs causing hypothyroidism are ethionamide and PAS

Cycloserine causes adverse effects of neuro psychosis

Pyrazinamide causes adverse effects of hyperuricemia, hepatotoxicity

Streptomycin causes ototoxicity, muscle weakness and nephrotoxicity

questions.text: Which is the active metabolite of Cyclophosphamide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

4-hydroxy Cyclophosphamide

The active metabolite of Cyclophosphamide is 4-hydroxy Cyclophosphamide. Hydroxycyclophosphamide
may be oxidized further by aldehyde oxidase, either in liver or in tumor tissue, to inactive metabolites. 4-Hydroxycyclophosphamide and its tautomer, aldophosphamide, travel in the circulation to tumor cells, where aldophosphamide cleaves spontaneously, generating stoichiometric amounts of phosphoramide mustard and acrolein. Phosphoramide mustard is responsible for antitumor effects, while acrolein causes hemorrhagic cystitis often seen during therapy with cyclophosphamide

Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent with antitumor and immunosuppressant properties. It is used for many solid tumors. Important side effects are cystitis due to metabolite Acrolein and bladder Carcinoma.
